Geological, geophysical, and inherited tectonic imprints on the climate and contrasting coastal geomorphology of the Indian peninsula

The Indian subcontinent comprises accreted cratonic fragments that underwent subsequent rifting–subduction– collision processes along major mobile belts. It is also a storehouse of a prolonged history of crustal evolution involving repeated episodes of magmatism, volcanism, sedimentation, and metamorphism, and the formation of intracratonic and foreland basins. The geologic–geomorphic evolution of the Peninsula is recorded in relic faults/suture zones that confine Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic sedimentary basins and landforms. In addition, escarpments, plateaus, waterfalls, deltas, planation surfaces, and strandlines are either aligned parallel and/or formed over them. Asymmetric relief across thewestern–eastern parts of the Peninsula, orographic effect on the precipitation pattern and climatic zones provide important constrains on the geologic and geomorphic evolution of the region. Though extensive continental and coastal deposition occurred during Permo-Triassic and Early Cretaceous, only the downwarped grabens of Gondwana basins preserved the sedimentary records. Occurrences of extensive Cenozoic deposits offshore and Neogene–Holocene deltaic deposits along the entire east coast as opposed to the absence of comparable deltaic sequences in the west coast are linked to intense and recurrent episodes of denudation indicating first-order control of basement structures over landscape evolution. Inheritance and continuum of basement structures over climate, and landscape evolution of Peninsular India can also be witnessed by the unique and diverse drainage patterns of major rivers. While most of the major rivers follow a general easterly direction, the landscape morphology of their catchments indicates youthful character and tectonically active nature. The east flowing rivers show an asymmetry between the areal extents of drainage basin size and delta,whereas thewest-flowing rivers are short and straight and their catchments areminiscule in comparisonwith the rivers flowing toward east. TheWestern Ghats Escarpment forms an orographic barrier and acts as themain divide between these two drainage systems. There is a disparity between the quanta of sediment discharge aswell. In addition, the eastern andwestern parts of India, across theWestern Ghats Escarpment, show significant differences in terms of climatic zones (humid to per-humid on thewestwhile it is arid to subhumid on the east). The west coast is characterized by N3000 mm/year annual rainfall, that often reaches N5000mm/year, dominance of SWmonsoonwinds, occurrence of narrow (b60 km), rocky, crenulated and coastal cliffs and pocket beaches, and net southerly long shore sediment transport. In contrast, the east coast is characterized by several hundred kilometers wide deltaic low lands built by major rivers. These rivers show trellis to dendritic stream patterns and follow major basement faults that are associated with geologic–historic–recent seismic activity. The sedimentary basins and delta heads, strandlines, and active delta lobes whose western boundary is always limited by basement faults have shown activity since the formation of the Gondwanan supercontinent. The eastern coastal region is also different from the west in terms of active NE monsoon, long shore sediment transport (toward north), and the formation of extensive lagoon-beach barrier systems sinceNeogene that in turn continue to occur until recent. Here we propose a conceptual tectono-geomorphic model demonstrating the inheritance and continuum of Gondwanan structural trends on the transient landscape of Peninsular India.

1. Introduction
sections.text:
The modes of extension and thinning of continental lithosphere control evolution of passive margins and thus investigations on the evolution of passive margins help to establish the genetic link between tectonics, geomorphology, and sedimentation (Dev et al., 2012). This is because denudation, sediment supply, and the resultant topographic and structural responses are intrinsically and dynamically linked (Campanile et al., 2007). Tectonics and climate play first-order controls on landscape evolution (Goodbred, 2003; Zhang, 2005), whereas lithology and slope provide subsidiary controls. In the coastal regions, shoreline dynamics as a result of complex interactions between sea level– climate–tectonics–subsidence–sediment influxes play a crucial role in landscape evolution. Geomorphic processes interact with tectonics and climate as an integrated system (Goodbred, 2003; Zhang, 2005). Until recently, geomorphology and tectonics were studied separately and drainage systems were analyzed in a fixed framework, with explanations involving only regional tectonics. Only a few studies related the evolution of drainage systems to plate movements, although drainage-controlled topographic feedbacks affected large-scale tectonics (Brookfield, 1998; Zhang, 2005).
The Indian subcontinent (Fig. 1) is an assemblage of rifted and welded polyhistoric cratons, intracratonic basins,mobile belts, and foreland basins. It is a storehouse of N3.8 Ga of geological history spanning from the Eoarchean to Recent (Santosh et al., 2014, 2015), involving extensive volcanism, plutonism, metamorphism, sedimentation, and tectonic deformation. India has a 7517 km long coastline (Guleria and Edward, 2012) including themainland coast line of ca. 5400 km. Extensive deltas occur only along the east coast and no comparable deltas occur along thewest coast (Fig. 2a). Although both eastern andwestern coasts of India represent rifted passive continental margins (Chatterjee et al., 2013), it is unique and ironic that the rivers that originate at few tens of kilometers from the west coast travel thousands of kilometers to drain at the east coast, whereas only estuaries and tidal creeks that deliver sediments directly into the shelf (Wagle et al., 1994; Vora et al., 1996) characterize thewest coast. Migration of axial river systems in response to lateral ground tilting by basement tectonics is known from many large continental river basins (Peakall et al., 2000; Valdiya, 2001a, 2001b). The Indian peninsular drainage is antecedent to the Western Ghats uplift (Sheth, 1999; Gunnel et al., 2003), which is interpreted to be a post-Deccan trap feature (Sheth, 2007) caused by the cymatogenic upwarp of the crust along an axis west of the
present-day Western Ghats Escarpment (WGE)—(Fig. 1) and resultant easterly tilt of the Indian plate (Radhakrishna, 1993). The presence of extensive deltas along the east coast and their absence in the west coast, development of failed rifts, occurrences of Gondwanan (this term is utilized hereinafter in the context of all those features “inherited” from the Gondwana supercontinent, of which the Indian subcontinent was an integral part; Collins et al., 2014 and references therein) sedimentary basins, development of Late Jurassic–Early Cretaceous rift basins coeval with rifting of the Gondwana supercontinent (hereinafter referred to as “Gondwanaland” for the landmass prior to Permian–Triassic rifting, following Collins and Pisarevsky, 2005) are all major features of this region, although received only scant attention on a spatially restricted scale (e.g., Kale, 2014; Kale and Vaidyanadhan, 2014; Tandon et al., 2014). Previous studies focused on the structural (Gombos et al., 1995) and geomorphic evolution of the Western Continental Margin (WCM) and WGE (Gunnel et al., 2003), respectively.
The Indian subcontinent encompasses a variety of geological formations ranging from Archean to Recent (Fig. 2b), and preserves tectonic structures, topographic features, and climatic zones related to the complex evolutionary history of these periods. Since 130 Ma, India had crossed southern latitudinal and climatic zones from polar region– tropic–northern latitudes, experienced largest continental flood basalt eruption events, orogenic events, and sustained seismicity (Fig. 2c). Thus, envisaging a simple easterly tilt and resultant drainage alignment and geomorphic evolution may not be appropriate for the prevailing structural–geomorphic and climatic complexity. Extensive studies have been carried out on the tectonic (Acharyya and Lahiri, 1991; Balakrishnan, 2001; Banerjee et al., 2001; Biswas, 2005; Banerjee et al., 2008; Lal et al., 2009; Dev et al., 2012), geomorphic (Reddy and Shah, 1991; Agarwal et al., 1996; Nair, 1999; Allison et al., 2003; Avinash et al., 2013), and basin evolution (Banerji, 1984; Mathur and Nair, 1993; Chari et al., 1995; Radhakrishna et al., 2000; Jayalakshmi et al., 2004) histories of the Indian sedimentary and river basins, coastal deltas, and offshore regions. Although these studies applied a variety of tools (e.g., Singh et al., 1998; Ramkumar, 1999; Kunte and Wagle, 2000; Ramkumar, 2000; Ramkumar et al., 2000; Karisiddaiah et al., 2002; Ramkumar, 2003; Ramkumar et al., 2004, 2005; Bhatt and Bhonde, 2006; Campanile et al., 2007; Ramkumar, 2008; Sensarma et al., 2008; Ramkumar et al., 2011, 2013; Kale and Vaidyanadhan, 2014; Sinha and Tandon, 2014), there has not yet been a systematic synthesis to understand the coastal geomorphic evolution at a continental scale. Elsewhere, control of inherited structures on sedimentation
pattern and geomorphology have already been reported (e.g., Menier et al., 2006; Menier et al., 2010; Estournès et al., 2012; Gomes et al., 2014; Menier et al., 2016); however, reports on continuance of structural inheritance on a long-term geological and continental scales remain scarce.
In this work, through compilation of data on structural styles, basin fill facies, stratigraphy and depositional characteristics of the east and west coast sedimentary basins, macroscale geomorphology, and geophysical characteristics of Peninsular India, we attempt to
a) examine structural and climatic controls on the landscape evolution, b) elucidate the sequence of major tectono-geomorphic events, and c) demonstrate through a conceptual model the inheritance and con-
tinuance of Gondwanan structural elements.

sections.heading: 2. Geology and geomorphology of the Indian peninsula
2.1. Geology
sections.text: The basement rocks of the Indian Peninsular Shield are dominantly composed of granites and granitic gneisses. The exposed Precambrian basement comprises four major cratons, namely, the Dharwar, Aravalli, Singbhum, and Bastar (Figs. 1, 2). In the southernmost part of the Peninsula, south of the Dharwar Craton, is a series of crustal blocks ranging in age from Archean to latest Neoproterozoic, welded together by intervening suture zones, and is termed as the Southern Granulite Terrane (Santosh et al., 2015 and references therein). 2.1.1. East coast
sections.text:
The ECM is a 2600 km long rifted passive margin evolved through separation of India–Antarctica–Australia from the Gondwanaland during Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous. The cratonic margin consists of rifted grabens and sags near shelf and deep water basins in offshore areas. This breakup had also truncated the NW–SE trending Godavari and Mahanadi rift valleys by transverse faults (Fig. 1). Four stages of magmatism i.e. Early Cretaceous (Rajmahal equivalents—Kerguelen and Crozet plumes—Bastia et al., 2010; Radhakrishna et al., 2012a), post-Albian, K/T (Deccanmagmatism), and post-Eocene are documented that have influenced tectonic process and structural styles. During its evolution, the Bay of Bengal (BOB) lithosphere had encountered two major hotspots, namely, the Kerguelen and the Crozet, and gave rise to the emplacement of linear N–S trending aseismic 90°E and the 85°E ridges, respectively (Fig. 1).
East coast of India is geomorphologically (Figs. 3, 4) and tectonically (Fig. 5) segmented due to subcrustal distinctions (Lal et al., 2009; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012) into Bengal/Ganges, Mahanadi, Godavari, Krishna, and Cauvery basins/deltas. Each of these subcrustal blocks behaved differently and mimicked the inherent subcrustal mosaic during the Gondwana period and carved out for itself an exclusive basin of Mesozoic–Cenozoic age (Lal et al., 2009). Salient geological, tectonic, stratigraphic, and evolutionary histories of selected basins are summarized in the Table 1. All the east coast basins are connected to open sea in the east and bordered on the west by highlands and the discontinuous Eastern Ghats. These basins also developed into deltaic systems since Neogene (Singh and Swamy, 2006) that have been shaping the east coast of India. Evolutionary history, drainage basin characteristics, dominant structural, geomorphic, climatic, coastal hydrodynamic, and other characteristics of east coast deltas are summarized in the Table 2. Fig. 6 depicts the sprawl of the catchment, morphology of coastal deltas, sediment and water discharge, coastal and oceanic current, and net sediment transport characteristics of the selected modern drainage basins and respective deltas.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. West coast
sections.text:
The 2200 km long WCM consists of Precambrian granites, Mesozoic sediments, Deccan flood basalts, and Paleocene to Recent sediments. The volcanic rocks of the shelf are deep, depleted, and fractionated. The sedimentary basins of the WCM consist of thinned continental crust (stretched to nearly 50%) and overlain by volcanogenic, volcaniclastic, and terrigenous sediments.
The WCM is a rifted passive continental margin (Gombos et al., 1995). Prominent among major structural features are the West coast fault, Panvel flexure, Cambay rift, Kachchh rift, (Fig. 7) Laxmi and Laccadive–Chagos ridges, and Vishnu Fracture (Fig. 1). Block faulting owing to extensional tectonics, thinning, and shear rifting and uplift of Western Ghats affected the coastal tract and manifest through several major lineaments. The edge of the continental shelf of the west coast is remarkably straight, representing a fault line that formed/reactivated during Late Pliocene time (Jayalakshmi et al., 2004). Several basement arches trending perpendicular to the west coast divide the shelf region into sedimentary basins, namely, the Kachchh, Saurashtra, Mumbai (Ratnagiri), Konkan, and Kerala basins along the western offshore of India (Table 1). The rift–drift events related to the separation of Madagascar during the mid-Cretaceous and the Seychelles in Late Cretaceous from India when Indian Plate moved above the Marion Plume (Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003) gave rise to the formation of major offshore rift basins (Storey et al., 1995). In the northernmost part, the Kutch and the Saurashtra basins are separated by a southwesterly plunging basement high, termed as the Saurashtra Arch (Biswas, 1987). The major conjugate rift systems, the Narmada and the Cambay, cross each other at south of the Saurashtra peninsula in the Surat offshore and form a deep Surat depression (Fig. 7). According to Biswas (1987), the northern part of the west coast was the first to be subjected to continental rifting since the Late Triassic giving rise to
three pericontinental Mesozoic marginal rift basins in the onshore such as the Kutch, the Narmada, and the Cambay basins. The subsurface geology and depositional and tectonic history of the Konkan–Kerala (KK) offshore have a genetic linkage to the denudational and uplift history of theWestern Ghats (Gunnell and Radhakrishna, 2001). Generalized structural styles of three major transects across the WCM are presented in Fig. 8.

sections.heading: 2.2. Geomorphology
sections.text: Geomorphology of Peninsular India can be broadly classified into eastern and western coastal zones (Fig. 1); Mysuru, Deccan, Malwa, and Bastar plateaus (Figs. 2, 9); WGE (Fig. 7); and southwestern high mountains (Fig. 2). There are two more escarpments, namely, the Kaimur and the Narmada that also emerged as a result of post-collision reactivation of Gondwanan failed rifts. In this section, geomorphic details of the eastern and western coastal zones are presented.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. East coast
sections.text: The 2600 km long east coast of Peninsular India from Sundarbans (Fig. 3a) to Kanyakumari (Fig. 2) consists of river delta systems, vast coastal plains, and extensive fluvial and marine sedimentary deposits, etc., indicative of prograding nature of the coast. Most of the major easterly and southeasterly flowing rivers, viz., Ganga, Mahanadi, Godavari, Krishna, and Cauvery and a few minor rivers like Pennar, Palar (located between Krishna and Cauvery river deltas—Fig. 2), and Thamirabarani and Vaigai (located between south of Cauvery delta and Kanyakumari—Fig. 2) have developed deltaic platforms at their mouths. Despite this commonality, the deltaic systems of these rivers differ considerably from each other as a function of riverine influx, wave, tide, and a myriad of variety of morphological, climatological, and environmental parameters (Table 2). These major rivers discharge large quantities of sediments to thedeltaic system (Fig. 6) and to the offshore regions as well, building one of the largest (Tripathy et al., 2011) and thickest (Fig. 10) subaqueous fans of the world, the Bengal fan. The east coast has been prograding since inception, as evidenced by the prevalent cyclic sedimentation and subsidence and a general thickening of Mesozoic, Tertiary, and Quaternary basinfill from onland toward offshore. Large lagoons/brackish lakes namely, the Chilka (Fig. 3b), Kolleru (Fig. 4a), Pulicat, and Muthupet (Fig. 4c) among many others, also occupy the coastal plain.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. West coast
sections.text:
The west coast is essentially limited by the WGE (Fig. 7). The WGE forms a prominent orographic feature (Fig. 9) with a linear relief zone (Sukhtankar, 1995) along the western fringe of the Indian Peninsula. It came into existence as a result of separation of Madagascar–Seychelles fromGreater India around 88–80Ma. It extends fromTapi valley located north of Mumbai to the southern tip of Kanyakumari for a distance of about 1600 km. The plateau–escarpment is very prominent in the northern part. The average elevation of the escarpment is around 1200 m. The escarpment is bounded on the landward side by plateaus of more than 800 m elevation along most of its length (Figs. 2, 9). Many embayments along the length of the escarpment, due to the influence of headward erosion of westerly-flowing streams occur (Fig. 7) among which, the 80 km wide Palghat Gap is the largest (Campanile et al., 2007). WGE acts as a major catchment divide, between the east flowing Godavari, Krishna, and Cauvery river systems and the westflowing short rivers. The Western Ghats is the wettest region in the Indian Peninsula with annual rainfall up to 5000 mm (Fig. 9). The highest peak Anaimudi [2695m abovemean sea level (amsl)] is located at its southern extremity.
Wide semi-arid plains located north of Surat, Great and Little Ranns along the coast form the northern limits of the west coast. The Saurashtra coast has a crenulated rocky shoreline with channels, submerged islands, sand bars, dunes, mudflats, and saltpans. Further south, Late

The 30–50 km wide Konkan coast is undulating lowland. It encompasses numerous hills and detached ridges amidst the lowland area characterized by flat shores with long sandy spits. The southern part of the Konkan coast is rugged and has high hills and elevated plateaus cut by numerous creeks. Further south, wide estuaries mark the coast around Goa. These are followed toward west by coastal plains with a topographic elevation of 10 m (amsl) interspersed by hills. The short and fast flowing nature of the rivers resulted in formation of estuaries and lakes along the crenulated coastline amidst narrow discrete zones of beach plains.
The coastal landscape near Mangalore in the Netravati valley has a frequent river mouths, creeks, promontories, and cliffs. Towards south, the lowland is relatively wide (~70 km). Three broadly parallel belts of landform can be recognized in this region, viz., coastal plains (up to 30 m amsl), 20 km wide erosional platform (between 30 and 60 m amsl), and isolated, denudation hillocks. Towards south, the 5–35 kmwide coast encompasses many estuaries, backwaters, lagoons, lakes, sand dunes, and rocky cliffs and documents the Pleistocene– Recent sea level and climatic fluctuations (Jayalakshmi et al., 2004). Low laterite plateaus and foothills occur toward east of alluvial coast in this region. The west coast terminates near the rocky outcrops at Kanyakumari.

sections.heading: 2.3. Climate and rivers
sections.text:
The Indian Ocean is the only tropical ocean that is entirely bounded by a landmass to the north. In boreal summer, this unique geographical setting allows for a large differential heating between the Asian subcontinent and the ocean to the south that drives the most dramatic monsoonal wind system in the world (Chaitanya et al., 2014). Driven by transequatorial pressure differences which, when coupled with the insulation difference between the Northern and Southern subtropical Hemispheres, the Indian monsoons produce one of the spectacular spatio-temporal variations. These temporal climate variations sharemajor elements on the orbital obliquity and precessional band with the SPECMAP marine oxygen isotope record, representing global ice volume (Leuschner and Sirocko, 2003). These monsoon systems are also influenced by El Niño, La Niña, Indian Ocean dipole, and Walker circulation in the equatorial Pacific and cover a large region spreading from Africa to Southeast Asia including India (Chauhan et al., 2013).
India receives about 4000 km3 precipitation annually including snowfall; out of which, about 3000 km3 is from SW (June to September) and NE (October to December) monsoonal rainfall (Kumar et al., 2005). The SWmonsoon covers entire peninsula, except southeastern extremity, and accounts for ~80% of the total rainfall (http://nwda.gov.in; http://india-wris.nrsc.gov.in) within a short span of four months from June to September. Orographic influence is dominant in the distribution of rainfall in the SW season, as the prevailingwinds blow at right angles against the Western Ghats. The monsoonal precipitation is highly spatio-temporally heterogeneous and produces a variety of climatic zones (Fig. 9), from Evergreen tropical rainforest, humid, semi-humid, and to hot–dry climes that constitute India, one of the wettest and heaviest snowfall regions of the world, to the hottest deserts. For example, the sparsely vegetated (mainly grass and shrub cover) peneplain region of the uplifted Mysuru plateau with semi-arid tropical climate (mean annual rainfall b1000 mm) grades within a few tens of kilometers into the Western Ghats, with green vegetative cover in a subhumid climatic setting. Themean annual precipitation in this part of the Ghats section is as high as 4000mm at an average annual temperature of 25 °C. In summer (March to May), the temperature reaches about 40 °C. The SW monsoon accounts for 75% of the annual rainfall, 73% of the water discharge, and 85% of the annual sediment transport (Rao, 1975).
During SW monsoon, water vapor collected at the ocean surface by powerful southwesterly winds is flushed over India and the BOB. A large fraction of the runoff to the ocean occurs during or shortly after the SW monsoon and contributes to freshwater flux into the BOB in equal proportion with rainfall over the ocean (Chaitanya et al., 2014). After the end of SWmonsoon, the NE monsoon sets in and it is characterized by a relatively dry season with less rainfall. The annual mean rainfall distribution along the coastal tracts of the country (Fig. 9) is in contrast between the west and east coasts. Along the west coast, it ranges from 300 mm in the northern and northwestern parts to 2500 mm in the southern part, with a maximum of more than 5000 mm in some areas of the Western Ghats forming second highest rainfall in the country. Along the east coast, the rainfall distribution is almost reversed, with higher rainfall of 600–1000 mm in the northern parts and relatively less in the southern parts within the range of 200– 600 mm.
The BOB, along the eastern coast, receives huge volumes of river discharge from large fluvial systems, namely, Ganga–Brahmaputra, Mahanadi, Krishna, Godavari, and Cauvery. In addition, relatively smaller rivers, namely, the Subarnarekha, Baitarani, Vamsadara, Rishikulya, Ponnaiyar, Gadilam, Adyar, Vellar, Vaigai, and Thamiraparani also drain the plains of east coast. Coastal streams, especially in the west, are short and episodic.
The coastal areas of India show wide variations in drainage characteristics regionally. In the northernmost part of west coast, two distinct sets of rivers, the Rupen, Saraswati, and Banas in the NW part, flow into the Rann of Kachchh, while the major rivers draining the central and southern coast, viz., Narmada, Tapi, Sabarmati, and Mahi, discharge into theGulf of Khambhat. Down south,many rivers, namely, Saraswati, Bhadar, Rupen, and Machundri originate in the central plateau region of Saurashtra and meander in a radial pattern through plains to meet the Arabian Sea. Only a few rivers like Khari, Nagmati, and Luni flow in the Kachchh. These rivers show highly varied drainage patterns (Fig. 7) depending on the lithology of region over which they flow (Kar, 1993; Prasad et al., 1998) such that braided in basalt, dendritic in upper reaches, and straight in limestone terrain. The rivers, viz., Konkan, Pinjal, Vaitarna, Bhatsai, and Ulhas drain a relatively narrow strip of land (b100 km width). Although the general slope is westward, a number of rivers and streams also have north–south alignment in certain stretches, displaying structural control. Further south, the rivers Netravati, Gurupur, Gangoli, Hangarkatta, Sharavathi, Aganashini, Gangavali, Kalinadi Kumaradhara, Nandini, Shambavi, Swarna, Zuari, and Mandovi drain the coastal area. The coastal plain of Kerala is drained by a large number of rivers and their tributaries originate from the Western Ghats. The main rivers originating from the Western Ghats are Chandragiri, Kuppam, Beypore, Bharatapuzha, Periyar, Meenachil, Pampa, and Manimala, etc. The rivers viz., Periyar, Achankovil, Manimala, Muvattupuzha, Kallada, and Ittikara run for small distances and debouch into the Vembanad or Ashtamudi lakes.

sections.heading: 2.4. Coastal hydrodynamics

littoral/longshore current or Coramandal Coastal Current (CCC) along the coastal margin (Fig. 6) reverses twice a year under the influence of alternating monsoons. It flows northward from February to September and southward from October to January. Heavy discharges from Ganges–Brahmaputra and BOB as a result of intense SWmonsoon result in 100 km wide freshwater lens floating over saline water. This current slowly withdraws from north of Kanyakumari during the middle of September and flows northward during rest of the year (Chaitanya et al., 2014). The deeper part of the BOB experiences clockwise circulation (BOB Current or BBC—Fig. 6), seemingly driven by the thermal differential between the Arabian and Indian coastal regions having contrasting atmospheric and sea surface temperatures. The west coast forming the western boundary of the Arabian Sea experiences anticlockwise current (Sanil Kumar et al., 2006; Malabar Current or MC—Fig. 6), probably driven by prevailing winds and wave refraction (Avinash et al., 2013). Both the coastal and deeper regions of Arabian Sea show a net southerly sediment transport (Kunte and Wagle, 1993; Kunte, 1994; Sanil Kumar et al., 2006). Owing to the general topographic slope and the absence of any major riverine influx, the southerly sediment transport continues unabated, often extending into the Palk Strait region (Fig. 6) of the east coast (Sanil Kumar et al., 2006).
Wind speeds at 10 m (amsl) height ranges from 39 to 50 m/s along both the coasts; however, higher speeds are always associated along the east coast than the west coast (Sanil Kumar et al., 2006). A wide range of wave heights (0.2–16 m) are observed along the Indian coastline. During fair-weather seasons, all along the Indian Peninsular coast, the wave heights are centered around 0.5–2.2 m and are controlled by bottom topography owing to the highly varied sediment delivery by the rivers (quantum, rate, and loci) and the structural control over the continental margin (distance from coast and slope) and resultant dynamics in the breaker zone. Wave influence on coastal zones and deltas varies considerably depending on the coastal morphology and nearshore bathymetry (Anthony, 2015). During fair-weather seasons, waves approaching the east coast are always at an angle (Ramkumar, 2003), a common feature observable in coasts experiencing predominantly swells.
The Indian Ocean is bordered on the north entirely by landmass that promotes the BOB to act as a nursery for cyclones and storms (Allison et al., 2003), and supercyclones almost annually, accompanied by N12 m waves. Hence, shoreline morphology is significantly influenced by waves, particularly associated with inclement weather. As deltas, lowlands, and/or tidal creeks cover the east coast, the onshore–offshore sediment transport dynamics are also influenced by the cyclones. As most of the coastal zones are located within mean sea level to 10 m amsl (Ramkumar, 2001; Allison et al., 2003), the inland reach of these cyclones (that always accompanymonsoonswhich in turn brings in excessive discharge) is attenuated (Ramkumar, 2009). The fair-weather seasons, as they are devoid of significant riverine influx and powerful currents or waves, could not rework the storm-resultant morphologies (Anthony, 2015). This phenomenon preserves the storm-generated morphologies along the coast as observed elsewhere (e.g., Simarro et al., 2015). Thus, all along the coast, behind the berm zone toward land, extensive low lands, in the form of bay, back water, and lagoon, namely, Pichavaram, Pulicot, Kolleru, and Chilika are formed (Ramkumar, 2003). All the deltaic systems of the east coast are reported (Singh and Swamy, 2006) to have possessed similar lowlands during prehistoric times as well, suggestive of the control exercised by the storm-influenced coastal morphologies also in the geologic past. The wave climate of the west coast varies regionally and has significantly affected the coastal morphology in terms of extensive backwaters in the south, cliff and wave-cut platforms in the middle and extensive tidal flats in the north. Similar to the east coast, the west coast is also subjected to seasonal–annual recurrence of cyclones and storms; however, the effects of which are not as dramatic as in the east due to the generally raised coastal lands.
Both the coasts experience diurnal and seasonal tidal asymmetries and show increase of tidal range from south to north. While a range of 0.2–4 m is observed from Kanyakumari–Ganges mouth, a range of 0.2–10m is observed along thewest coast. The funnel-shaped estuarine mouths of Ganges and Rann of Kachchh, that are located in northern extremes of east and west coast respectively, geomorphic amplification of tidal range is observed.While the tidal waters inundate up to 100 km from coast in the Ganges, it ranges up to 160 km in the Kachchh.

sections.heading: 3. A continuum of Gondwana tectonics
3.1. Macrogeomorphic evolution controlled by inherited structures
sections.text:
Themacrogeomorphic subdivisions of Peninsular India are such that 2600 m topographic contour delineates the WGE, 500 m contour the plateaus, 100 m contour the maximum seaward limit of Neogene– Pre-Quaternary terraces, 30 m contour the Pleistocene terraces, 10 m contour defines the Holocene delta heads and only the regions below 5 m contour are active delta lobes (Figs. 3, 4). As explicit in the Figs. 1, 2, and 9, all these delineated zonal boundaries are, without exception, either aligned or located along or in close proximity with underlying Precambrian, Permo-Triassic, Late Jurassic–Early Cretaceous, Late Cretaceous, or Neogene–Quaternary–Recent structural trends, suggestive of continuum of topographic/geomorphic evolution under primary tectonic control and ongoing landscape evolution. The data, our corresponding observations and inferences, together with the mismatch between areal extents of drainage basin and deltas of major river systems (Fig. 6) and the quantities of sediment delivered at the river mouth (see inset histograms and areal distribution in the Fig. 6 and compare with the areal extents of drainage basins and deltas in Table 2) confirm the transient nature of the Indian landscape.
In the paleogeographic position of Indian Subcontinent, Collins et al. (2014) stated, “southern India lay in an interesting location in Gondwana. To the west (with reference to the present geographic co-ordinates of India), lay Madagascar and East Africa beyond that; to the east lay Sri Lanka and East Antarctica with Australia lying to the north of that; to the south lay Dronning Maud Land (East Antarctica) and Mozambique to the southwest.” From this assembly, initial rifting of India occurred during the Permo-Triassic to create Gondwana basins. Biswas (2005) and Roy (2004) suggested that the failed rifts of Permo-Triassic (generating the Gondwana basins) were themselves inherited precursors of Precambrian faults. This Permo-Triassic rift was in the form of linked rift triple junctions. These aulacogens formed extensive fluvial systems, denuded the cratonic hinterland and the resultant sediments were deposited in the Gondwana basins (Narmada–Son, Bengal, Mahanadi, and Godavari—Figs. 1, 5). Actual separation of India (continental splitting or pull-apart phase) from the Gondwana supercontinent commenced at around 128–130 Ma. This event is marked by M0–M5 magnetic lineations of Early Cretaceous (Chand et al., 2001). The rifting was aligned parallel to the structural trend of the Eastern Ghats that defines the configuration of the eastern continental margin and partly the present coastline of eastern India (Gombos et al., 1995). It appears from the structural, stratigraphic, and sediment infill that this Early Cretaceous rifting commenced from the Bengal Basin (Banerji, 1984) and proceeded toward south (present day), as similar rifts, synrift, and post-rift sedimentation occur in all the sedimentary basins, except in the case of the Cauvery Basin wherein shearing–rifting (Radhakrishna et al., 2012a, 2012b) commenced during Barremian at about 120– 118Ma (Ramkumar et al., 2004, 2011). Based on cross-spectral correlation between gravity and bathymetry (collected from ship and satellitederived gravity data) across the ECM and across the conjugate East Antarctica Margin, Chand et al. (2001) concluded that the ECM is a composite of two segments, one north of Cauvery Basin with rifted margin character, and the other, inclusive of the Cauvery Basin and southern part of Indianplatewith transform-rift character. This explains the differential timing and structural traits of the Cauvery Basin. These
authors also reasoned that these two regions had different crustal elastic thicknesses (N25 km and b5 km for north and south, respectively) which explained the causative mechanism for the observed structural evolutionary difference.
As could be visualized from the structural styles and sedimentary fills of the east coast basins (Table 1), multiple episodes of basin differentiation in terms of normal faulting and resultant horst–graben structures (Fig. 5) occurred and continued from Early Cretaceous–Cenozoic, progressively shifting the principal loci of deposition from cratonic interior toward continental margin. This might be a result of basement tectonics enforced by rising mantle plume (Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003; Müller, 2011; van Hinsbergen et al., 2011; Koptev et al., 2015) beneath cratonic center that might have moved toward margin and consumed subcrustal lithosphere intensively along the margins and preexistent lithospheric weak zones/structural trends. Movement of plumehead initially along the eastern margin from Bengal Basin up to the Cauvery Basin, prevalence of rifting–shearing in the Cauvery Basin, followed by movement of the plumehead along the western margin are analogous with the processes in the Tanzanian craton (Koptev et al., 2015). This inference is also supported by the general parallelism between structural trends of Gondwana basins and neoformed Upper Cretaceous–Cenozoic basins (Fig. 5). During this period, Indian plate was completely separated, rotated, and commenced its northerly drift through rift, pull-apart, sag, and tilt phases (Sastri et al., 1981; Acharyya and Lahiri, 1991; Chari et al., 1995; Lal et al., 2009). Cande and Stegman (2011) hypothesized that if a rising plume head impinges on the base of a tectonic plate long after supercontinent breakup and dispersal, its pushing force may result in a substantial transient acceleration or deceleration of
plates. van Hinsbergen et al. (2011) also concluded that the plume ascend and resultant plate motion could accelerate drift rates of continents at several cm/year.
Around 88–80 Ma, Madagascar–Seychelles separated from Greater India (Melluso et al., 2009), forming WCM, coast parallel deep crustal fault (west coast fault/WCF—refer Fig. 1), and a series of parallel faults that initiated the formation of WGE. Passing of the Indian plate over the Reunion hotspot during 68–64 Ma led to continental flood basalt volcanic episode and the Panvel flexure (Hooper et al., 2010). Studies suggest that plume upwelling resulted in uplift of the Indian plate (Gunnel et al., 2003; Singh et al., 2007) and was tilted toward east (Gunnell and Radhakrishna, 2001), contributing to the rise of WGE (Harbor and Gunnell, 2007), inception of orographic effect (Gunnell, 1998a), water divide along the peaks (Kale, 2014; Kale and Vaidyanadhan, 2014), birth of precursors to the east flowing modern rivers and supply of sediments and water to the BOB. However, the rivers flowing to the north of Narmada–Son and debauching at the Arabian Sea are an exception, suggestive of the limiting of uplift and tilt by the Narmada–Son rift. The occurrences of escarpments along and north of Narmada–Son rift (Narmada and Kaimur escarpments—Fig. 1) suggest subcrustal lithospheric uplift related northerly and easterly tilt, instead of traditionally considered easterly tilt of Indian plate. After the rift–drift of Madagascar during 88–80 Ma, rift–drift of Seychelles during 68–64 Ma from the WCM, followed up northerly drift and the collision of India with Eurasia around ~54 Ma and anticlockwise rotation, subduction under Tibetan plate (Lippert et al., 2014), and ridge push from Carlsberg and Central Indian ridges (Banerjee et al., 2001) have all contributed to the tilt-related tectono-geomorphic evolution of the subcontinent. sections.heading: 3.2. Eastern or northern–eastern tilt?
sections.text:
In the first approximation, as few previous related publications (e.g., Sheth, 1999; Gunnel et al., 2003) assumed, it appears that the Peninsular drainage pattern of India is influenced by the easterly tilt of western margin. Radhakrishna (1993) and Gunnell et al. (2003)
stated that emergence of Western Ghats and easterly tilt of the Indian Peninsula along with Himalayan uplift due to collision of Eurasian– Indian plates during Miocene resulted in abundant clastic supply leading to start of deltaic deposition by Ganges–Brahmaputra, Mahanadi, Krishna–Godavari, and Cauvery Rivers all over east coast (Lal et al., 2009). The emergence of WGE, dated to be Late Cenozoic–Pleistocene, extends for about 1600 km all along the western margin. The Miocene–Recent tectonic uplift in the Raan of Kutchchh (Biswas, 1982, 1987, 2005) could be cited as evidence for the easterly tilt, driven by continued rifting since separation of India–Madagascar at around 88 Ma (Melluso et al., 2009; Chatterjee et al., 2013). At the macrogeomorphic level, togetherwith the structural trends and geological information, it can be surmised that the Indian subcontinent as a whole experiences thrust and tilt from south due to its continued northerly flight and collisionwith Eurasia since rifting fromGondwanaland together with rift and tilt toward NE from west. This is applicable essentially to the region south of the Narmada–Son Lineament. It
could also mean that the rate of rifting driven by Owen fracture is lesser than the Carlsberg rift. Alternatively, the compressional force from Owen fracture is being spent on the regional geodynamics of the Kachchh while the energy from Carlsberg is predominantly spent on uplift, and tilt of the Indian plate toward NE. Biswas (2005) suggested that the ongoing anticlockwise rotation of Indian plate, a phenomenon that was initiated since hard collision of Indian plate with Eurasia, is due to the rifting at the conjugate rift margin of the Kachchh–Cambay–Narmada–Son rifts. While the connectivity of anticlockwise rotation with the complex Kachchh–Cambay–Narmada–Son rift systems seems to be plausible, we interpret as effect–cause (continuance of rift and rotation—detailed later), rather than cause–effect. However, the involvement of Narmada–Son rift, active formation of escarpments at andnorth of it, prominent differences of drainages at north and south of it signify north–east tilt, rather than simple easterly tilt, particularly the peninsular region south of it.

Based on an evaluation of sequence of events of the continuing drift of Indian plate since breakup from Gondwanaland, Chatterjee et al. (2013) reported the occurrence of lower part of the Indian lithosphere along the Main Frontal Thrust underneath the Himalaya and Tibet up to 31°N (Mahesh et al., 2012; Lippert et al., 2014) and opined that such a dense continental slab with higher density could subduct under Tibet and provide a significant driving force for India–Asia convergence. The slab pull is reinforced by the ridge push from the spreading of the Carlsberg Ridge and Central Indian Ridge. These ridges push the Indian plate from south (e.g., Patriat and Achache, 1984; Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003; Cande and Stegman, 2011; Müller, 2011; van Hinsbergen et al., 2011; Jagoutz et al., 2015; Koptev et al., 2015 and references cited therein for the roles of plume dynamics on tectonism and plate motions). The continued activity of Narmada–Son rift, the pivotal role of conjugate margins of Cambay–Kachchh–Narmada–Son rifts, anticlockwise rotation of Indian plate, when evaluated with the aseismic nature of 95°E, 85°E ridges (Bastia et al., 2010; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012), relatively less significant ridge push from Owen Fracture (due to the intervening WCF and Panvel Flexure and many other subcrustal faults of parallel and transverse alignments), it is perfectly conceivable that the Peninsular India underwent and currently experiences north–east tilt. It is also perceivable that owing to the alignments of conjugate margins of Kachchh region and the Owen fracture, the ridge push promotes anticlockwise rotation (N20o)—(Chatterjee et al., 2013), perhaps aided by the strike–slip along WCF rather than easterly tilt. Occurrences of well-defined incised fluvial channel fills in the shelf off Mangalore coast at a bathymetry of 65 m, escarpment
and relative absence of major deltaic systems along the west coast, together with establishment and persistence of major deltaic systems along the east coast since the breakup from the Gondwanaland, general unroofing of sediments and occurrences of only the deep crustal cratonic rocks in the southern edge of the continent and crustal thickness of only 29 km (A. Singh et al., 2015; P. Singh et al., 2015) with highest peaks of Western Ghats at its SW extremity, namely, Anaimudi (2695 m amsl) and Dota Petta (2637 m amsl) and absence of significantly thick regolith in the vicinity on a regional scale (Sharma and Rajamani, 2000a, 2000b; Singh and Rajamani, 2001; Sensarma et al., 2008; P. Singh et al., 2015), progressive increase of thicknesses of regolith over granitic and laterite over trap rocks (Kale and Vaidyanadhan, 2014), and sediment pile from south to north point to this fact and support this inference.

sections.heading: 3.3. Continuum of tectonics along pre-existing structures
sections.text:
While examining rare earth element (REE) characteristics of flood plain sediments of the Holocene–Anthropocene Cauvery River, Sharma and Rajamani (2000a, 2000b) and Singh and Rajamani (2001) found the sediments to have been derived from charnockites that form high hills, in contrast to the general weatherability of granitic gneiss that form the basement. Together with the observed textural– mineralogical immaturity of the sediments, these authors reasoned that physical denudation as a result of continuing uplift of the Western Ghats in general and neotectonics in particular (Sharma and Rajamani, 2000a, 2000b) might have been the cause of the observed REE
signatures. Similar observation was made by Sensarma et al. (2008) on examination of the Hemavati River sediments, suggesting the phenomenon reported by Sharma and Rajamani (2000a, 2000b) and Singh and Rajamani (2001) to be regionally extensive (meaning basinal–continental scale). The unroofing of sediments and absence of significant regolith cover might have been a long lasted trait of this region as the prevalence of physical erosion, absence of chemical weathering, episodic bouts of clastic sediment flux into the Cauvery Basin during Barremian, Santonian, and Mio-Pliocene were also reported earlier (Ramkumar et al., 2005, 2011, 2013). All these features indicate that the rift, drift, and tilt characteristics of the Indian subcontinent since Cretaceous (Chari et al., 1995) were activated by the preexistent structures, resulting in continual unroofing of the high hills and plateaus. The recurrences of minor–major earthquakes (Banerjee et al., 2001; Roy, 2004; Biswas, 2005) preferentially concentrated along the basement faults (Fig. 2c) also support this assertion.
Biswas (2005) reported that the convergent transfer zone (the meeting point of Narmada–Son, Cambay, and Kachchh rifts) has been the focal point of major tectonic events (Kar, 1993) in the geologic past since Mesozoic as well as the epicenters of two major earthquakes of the 20th century and focal center of aftershock hypocenter, suggesting recurrent reactivation along preexistent structural weak planes. Many previous studies including Subrahmanya (1996), Rajendran (2000), Banerjee et al. (2001), and Murthy (2002) analyzed the past earthquake occurrences and found their association with displaced river channels, incised valleys, coastal and fluvial terraces, etc. Most importantly, in unison, these studies have stated the neoseismic events to have been caused by geodynamics of older, basement faults, and rifts of theGondwanaland, an inference also confirmed by another, independent study (Roy, 2004). Indian peninsular shield likemany other similar terrains of the world was believed to be stable, and having a strong, thick, and cold lithosphere. However, Indian shield is comparatively thin, warm tectonically active (Pandey et al., 2013; Pandey, 2015), as
evidenced by the periodic reactivations of preexistent sutures, shear zones, and faults, most of which were inherited from Precambrian (Biswas, 2005), particularly those from the Late Neoproterozoic Gondwanaland. Earthquake activity of moderate to large magnitudes in Peninsular India suggests that, tectono-thermally, the Indian plate has been and is active (Roy, 2004), albeit episodically until recent (Banerjee et al., 2001).
The occurrences and characteristics of the deltas along the east coast also extend credence to the geodynamics inferred above. The southeastern part of Indian subcontinent has only minor deltas of Thamirabarani and Vaigai (Table 2). Although they are considered to be perennial and originate from the Western Ghats, the receiving basins of these depict no significant sediment accumulation in the form of deltaic plains. These rivers deliver the sediment and water directly into the adjoining bay. The Kaveri River has built a broad and huge delta whose delta head starts at ~24 m amsl. The Palar and Pennar are the rivers that are located north of Kaveri River delta and have built deltas of their own (Singh and Swamy, 2006). Further north, the rivers Krishna, Godavari, and Mahanadi have created extensive deltas whose delta head start at 19m, 11m, and b10m amsl, respectively. All these deltas are Quaternary in origin and their active present-day lobe is of Holocene in age. These are delimited on the west by the EGMB thrust boundary (Fig. 1) and “possible tectonic line” (Yoshida et al., 1999) which is also marked by the axis of Bouger gravity high anomaly (Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003), meaning thin crust and denser subcrustal material beneath the EGMB. The observation of differential crustal thicknesses between either sides of this line (Singh et al., 2004) adds credence to the inference of greater role played by this tectonic line through reactivations since initial rift of Gondwanaland. Based on the intraplate stress computations and the history of earthquakes, Mandal (1999) suggested that the occurrences of intraplate earthquakes in the south Indian shield can be attributed to movement along old pre-existing shear zones (Banerjee et al., 2001; Roy, 2004), particularly in regions along the
