sections.text: EGMB, Cauvery Shear, etc., in response to the perturbation in the local stress regime due to topography, crustal density inhomogeneity and the dominant plate tectonic force in south India. He also stated that the principal stress directions suggest a dominance of strike–slip and reverse mode of deformation for south India, which support the inference of continued tectonic activity. On the north, the deltaic regimes are delimited by the Singhbhum craton and Narmada–Son failed rift lineament. These features are consistent with the greater tilt of the Indian plate at the southern tip, subduction at the NE extremity, a continuum of the geodynamics until present day since rifting from Gondwanaland and the influence of the inherited fault and shear zone tectonic elements over macrogeomorphic features.

sections.heading: 3.4. Subcrustal lithospheric and mantle plume processes and tectonic continuum
sections.text:
Based on the subsidence curves developed for each of the subbasins of the Cauvery Basin in the light of tectonic evolution of east coast sedimentary basins of India, Chari et al. (1995) suggested that the initial rifting commenced from cratonic interior, confirming the role of subcrustal plume (Patriat and Achache, 1984; Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003; Müller, 2011; Cande and Stegman, 2011; van Hinsbergen et al., 2011; Jagoutz et al., 2015; Koptev et al., 2015) and asthenospheric anisotropy/asymmetry (Sharma et al., 2012) in the tectonic evolution prior to, during, and after the breakup of Gondwana. Sen et al. (2009) documented the occurrences of metasomatized mantle xenoliths in the Kachchh region and supplemented their inferences with trace elemental compositional evidences, which support the notion of rising of plume from asthenosphere and the mantle–crust interaction (Patriat and Achache, 1984; Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003; Cande and Stegman, 2011; Müller, 2011; van Hinsbergen et al., 2011; Jagoutz et al., 2015; Koptev et al., 2015) of the Indian plate leading to the thinning of lithosphere (Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003). Given considerations to the tracks of plumes, distribution of trap rocks in the continental and offshore regions, and the gravity and seismic tomography based crustal thickness estimations, it can be inferred that the Kerguelen, Crozet, Marion, and Reunion plumes, on emergence and eruption, might have also significantly depleted the continental margins.
Crustal thickness estimations, as observed by Rao (2002) from zero free air gravity anomaly shows isostatic under-compensation (positive values, meaning thin crust) in the plateau regions, zero values in Western Ghats (normal crustal thickness), and negative values in the mobile belts (meaning thickened crust). He also reported the prevalence of isostatic equilibrium beneath theWestern Ghats, and abnormal crustal thickness beneath its western margin due to crustal downwarp extending beyond the limits of the topographic load of the mountain belt. According to him, sudden rise of mountains in the western margin caused downwarp due to elastic behavior of the crust and thus the compensation is of regional nature. High crustal velocity beneath the EGMB reveals the occurrence of dense crust. This is excess load within the crust and thus needs compensation similar to the regional topography. Thus, regional compensation can be expected with this mobile belt, causing crustal downwarp. Rao (2002) reasoned that the isostatic under-compensation leads to instability in the Koyna, Killari, Bellary, and Coimbatore areas that witnessed major earthquakes with magnitude 5.5 and above while a major fault (Bhavani–Mayor) marks its southern boundary. This information, together with the structural trends, their reactivation and thickened nature in the mobile belts, confirms the continuance of tectonic activity along the inherited structural elements. Srinagesh (2000) estimated the velocity residuals of Peninsular India through seismic tomography (Fig. 10) which show general agreement with the inferences of Rao (2002) and indicate the occurrence of deep-rooted crust in the order of 50–175 km in the northcentral, isolated patches along the western, and highly thinned crust in the southern parts of Peninsular India. Raval and Veeraswamy (2003) reported crustal thickness of N50 km in central India and
parts of western India. Radhakrishna et al. (2000) reported b38 km in southern India and ~30 km under the Krishna–Godavari Basin and a mere 20–23 km at eastern extremity of ECM at offshore Krishna– Godavari Basin near ocean–continent transition (Radhakrishna et al., 2012b). Based on two and half dimension gravity anomaly modeling, Singh et al. (2004) estimated a difference of crustal thicknesses between the WCM (37 km), western Dharwar craton (41 km), eastern Dharwar craton (38 km), and EGMB (b35 km). Subrahmanyam and Chand (2006) reported that the basement below the Cauvery Basin has only a ~3 km thick elastic lithosphere while the basement below the Krishna–Godavari Basin has 30 km elastic lithosphere. These two latter features also evidence the extensive subcrustal plume erosion along the continentalmargins and explain the greater crustal thickness associated with north and central part of the plate (Fig. 10) as well as the intensity trends from southern extremity to north.
A recent review of variations in crustal and upper mantle structure beneath the Indian subcontinent and its environs, based on more than 600 seismic stations, and over 10,000 km of deep seismic profiles, shows a range of crustal thickness from 29 km at the southern tip of India to 88 kmunder the Himalayan collision zone suggesting northerly tilt–uplift due to thrust and isostasy (Pandey et al., 2013). This review also revealed that although the Indian shield comprises a number of Archean cratons, only a minor portion of the initially formed upper crust remains in place now and a thick chunk of the original lower crust was consumed by the underlying thermally buoyant mantle due to subcrustal erosion. The signatures of repeated tectono-thermal activity can be traced since the beginning of Proterozoic to as late as Early Tertiary. These authors have documented a 16 km thick mantle plume with an isotherm of ~1300 °C at shallow depth (~100 km) and suggested that, owing to the subcrustal plume erosion, the Indian lithosphere is one of the thinnest (Pandey, 2015) when compared with the thicknesses of shield areas elsewhere that are 250–300 km thick. According to these authors, and Roy (2004), the Kerguelen, Crozet, Marion, and Reunion plumes which interacted with the Indian lithosphere between 65 and 110 Ma led to large-scale shearing of mantle lithosphere, intraplate magmatism, and magma underplating. This plume-related consequence, in addition to the crustal stretching and thinning, essentially along the EGMB, ECM, WCM, might have newly created faults and also structurally weakened the preexistent faults and shear zones (Radhakrishna et al., 2000; Roy, 2004; Singh et al., 2004), facilitated reactivations during synrift, post-rift and collisional phases and considerably reconstituted the Indian plate (Roy, 2004). Mishra and Kumar (2005) suggested asthenospheric upwarping along preexistent faults and thrusts, particularly along the Cauvery Shear and southern extremity of the SGT, in association with the heightened upper mantle heat flow beneath this region and seismic history suggested continuity of tectonic activity.
Continentalmargins are entities ofmixed character in termsof physiography and physical properties. The morphology of the continental margin is determined by its formation mechanism (rifting vs. shearing) and by processes that have subsequently operated on it (Chand et al., 2001). The information that significant erosion of Himalayan region and their deposition in the Bengal Basin as well as in the Bengal fan in the BOB that exceed N24 km in thickness (Subrahmanyam and Chand, 2006; Mikhailov and Dotsenko, 2007), occurrence of N70 km thick sediments in the Sylhet depression and in the region north of Swath of no ground (Bengal Canyon) and discharge of N1000 million tones of sediment annually from Ganges and Brahmaputra (Mikhailov and Dotsenko, 2007) warrant closer examination. The sediments deposited in subsided areas along the continental margin act as a top load on the lithosphere. Numerous studies at rifted margins showed that they are consistent with the flexure model of isostasy. The accommodation of these sediments and the depositional pattern suggest a flexural type of behavior since inception of rifting (Chand et al., 2001). Based on the observation of Chand et al. (2001), in combination with the enormous sediment thickness along the eastern continental margin, especially
85M. Ramkumar et al. / Gondwana Research 36 (2016) 65–93
along the northeast (Mikhailov and Dotsenko, 2007), we presume that this sediment loading may also cause accelerated subduction and drift and attenuate the uplift from south (by the push-force by plume and ridge tectonics), tilt from west (by the ridge push), causing the uplift and tilt a continuum. Although not related, but the cause of sediment accumulation is dealt in Armitage et al., 2014. We presume that the accumulated sediment load may cause additional drive as the region is getting subducted under Eurasian plate and is floating over the viscous dècollement. In effect, this is a vicious cycle that denudes the western and southern regions of Peninsula and supplies sediments to the fan. Subsidence studies in Cauvery, Krishna–Godavari, and Bengal basins along the ECM suggest that there is a progressive increase in extension rates from south to north (Chand et al., 2001), affirming this inference. Similar, but not identical mantle plume related uplift of continental interior, resultant isostatic compensation, denudation, and sediment deposition has also been reported from Rocky Mountains–Colorado Plateau (Armitage et al., 2014). Plate reconstruction theories and models of rifts/drifts often take into account intrinsicmagmatic processes as the critical operator of continental drifts (Cande and Stegman, 2011; Müller, 2011; van Hinsbergen et al., 2011; Koptev et al., 2015). However, they frequently overlook the inherent nature of these events that always work on differential rates and at highly discontinuous periodicity (Müller, 2011).

sections.heading: 3.5. Drainage and climatic influence
sections.text:
As shown in Figs. 1, 2, 7, and 9, almost the entire variation in precipitation over Peninsular India is controlled by orographic effect, which, in turn, has a structural control. Previous geomorphological and seismic studies on the Western Ghats documented periodic uplift since Middle Mesozoic until Holocene along Archean and Proterozoic faults and shear zones (Radhakrishna, 1993; Valdiya and Rajagopalan, 2000; Valdiya, 2001a, 2001b, 2008) and significantly since the commencement of Himalayan orogeny. It also led to the physiographical diversity and the youthful character of its mountain ranges (Sharma and Rajamani, 2000a, 2000b; Singh and Rajamani, 2001; Sensarma et al., 2008). Although the reversal of drainage flow directions was initiated by the evolution ofWGE (Fainstein et al., 2012), the role of its orographic impact in altering the climatic pattern of Peninsular India, and thereby, the sustenance of the topographic evolutionwith general north–east trend, needs examination.
From Figs. 2, 6, and 7 and the descriptions of Harbor and Gunnell (2007), it is apparent that the escarpment exhibits contiguous segments where scarp sinuosity, relief, stream orientation, spacing of scarp, coastline–continental divide, drainage basin shape, and other basin attributes show co-variation, suggesting differences in the process of retreat of the Western Ghats as a continuous yet heterogeneous landform. According to Harbor and Gunnell (2007), these along and across strike variations are site-specific feedbacks between climate, drainage and geologic structure while the large-scale plateau uplift influences the long-term atmospheric circulation patterns. Uplift of the Western Ghats across the path of the SW monsoon created a rain shadow effect for the Mysuru and the Deccan plateaus (Gunnell, 1998b). He has reasoned that the net climatic result of plateau uplift was to increase humidity on the windward side, due to the orographic effect, as well as on the immediate backslope of the escarpment and broadening the semi-arid tracts of the interior due to the rain shadow effect, and steepening the rainfall gradient in the transition region. Gunnell (1998b) further stated that the Miocene–Pliocene sandstones that occur all along the eastern coast and inland regions of India contain less weathered and unaltered feldspars, a sign of physical erosion meaning tectonic dynamism. He interpreted scouring of regolith before weathering due to relatively dry–warm climate; while the thick clay deposits that occur along the western coast, albeit coeval indicate wet–humid conditions of weathering. He had cited the work of Misra et al. (1996) who have reported the extinction of certain pollen taxa in the Mio-Pliocene
lignite deposits (east coast of India) due to the lasting climatic influence, but their survival in Gabon and Cameroon. These information, together with the report of the scarcity of thick weathering profiles in the catchments of Cauvery River (Sensarma et al., 2008) and the occurrences of immature sediments in the Cretaceous deposits of the Cauvery Basin (Ramkumar et al., 2005, 2011, 2013) as well as in the Recent channel bedload sediments and floodplains (Sharma and Rajamani, 2000a, 2000b; Singh and Rajamani, 2001), suggest the recurrent and continual tectonic activity. The orographic effect ofWGE and onset of modern climate were all existent since Miocene, at least in the Peninsular India. Most recent studies, involving multiproxies (Singhvi and Krishnan, 2014) and deep-sea high-resolution data (Pandey et al., 2015), opined that this SW monsoon became intense since 10–8 Ma. It signifies the attainment of orographic barrier effect of WGE during 10–8 Ma, commencement of significant planation process of the plateaus, and inheritance of drainage basin areas of modern rivers. Commencement of significant deltaic deposition (the locales of which were restricted/ controlled by the tectonic line—Fig. 1) also took place during this period, suggestive of tectonic control of climate and drainage-deltaic feedback on landscape evolution. As discussed earlier, denudation had influenced isostatic compensation, making the emergence of WGE–climatic control–denudation feedback, a continuum, explaining the youthful character of Peninsular Indian landscape and contrasting geomorphic features along east and west coasts.

sections.heading: 4. Tectono-geomorphic evolution
sections.text: The tectonic framework of the Indian subcontinent is a result of accretion of continental terranes since Mid-Archean, welding of Archean crustal blocks by large-scale Proterozoic mobile belts which were overprinted by Late Palaeozoic to Mesozoic and Tertiary intracontinental rift zones, that in turn owe their origin to the breakup of Gondwana and the subsequent northward drift of the Indian plate (Gombos et al., 1995; Kovac et al., 2010; Collins et al., 2014; Santosh et al., 2014, 2015). All these commencedwith the rifting during Permian (Sastri et al., 1981), probably associated with subcrustal plume activity that stretched and depleted the Archean basement (Roy, 2004). The rifts are now recognized as failed Narmada–Son, Godavari, and Mahanadi rift arms (Fig. 1). While the Narmada–Son extends from W–ENE and separates the Himalayan foreland from Peninsular India, the Godavari and Mahanadi rifts are aligned transverse to the EGMB. Chatterjee et al. (2013) summarized the tectonic evolution of the Indian plate from Late Jurassic and stated that it includes an exceptional and intricate history of events such as: continental breakup, sea-floor spreading, birth of new oceans, flood basalt volcanism, hotspot tracks, transform faults, subduction, obduction, continental collision, accretion, and mountain building. Important among these is the recurrent plume activity, namely, the Kerguelen, Crozet, Marion, and Reunion, all of which have interacted with the subcrustal and supracrustal parts of the Indian plate. Perhaps associated with the rifting, many subparallel normal faults originated that led to the formations of extensive, intracratonic Gondwana basins that provided loci for the accumulations of continental, brackish, and coastal marine deposits as the oldest deposits in the Bengal, north of Mahanadi, Krishna–Godavari, Pennar, and Palar basins of east coast of India (Banerji, 1984; Acharyya and Lahiri, 1991; Lal et al., 2009; Bastia et al., 2010; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012; Radhakrishna et al., 2012a, 2012b). Intriguing is the fact that, though major part of Gondwana deposition took place in epicontinental conditions andwere interpreted to be extensive, available records are few, limited in areal extent and restricted to the buried parts of the grabens suggesting intensive erosion, continued uplift of structural highlands, and downwarping of the grabens as a result of subcrustal processes. Intensification of the subcrustal plume activity during the Late Jurassic, now recognized as Kerguelen plume, might have depleted the eastern portions of these Gondwana basins that led to crustal downwarping, normal faulting, and creation of horst and

sections.heading: 86 M. Ramkumar et al. / Gondwana Research 36 (2016) 65–93
sections.text:
graben structures essentially parallel (Banerji, 1984; Acharyya and Lahiri, 1991; Roy, 2004) to the Gondwana basin structures. A case in point is the Bengal Basin (Fig. 5) that shows the uniform structural styles of Pre-Jurassic and Early Cretaceous signifying the continuation of Gondwanan trends while other basins followed less typically. The intensification of plume activity might have proceeded from north to south (present day) (Banerji, 1984; Patriat and Achache, 1984; Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003; Roy, 2004; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012; Pandey et al., 2013; Koptev et al., 2015; Ramkumar et al., 2016) and is why the Cauvery Basin came into existence finally (Sastri et al., 1981; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012) and does not have Early Jurassic deposits comparable to that of other ECM basins. However, the oldest exposed Sivaganga beds of the Cauvery Basin, interpreted to have been deposited in coastal plains and coastal marine depositional setting during Barremian synrift (Ramkumar et al., 2004) and Tabbowa/Andigama beds of Gondwana affinity (Chari et al., 1995) and occurrences of similar synrift-associated immature coastal conglomerates (physical weathering, higher rate of physical erosion) to predominantly kaolinite-rich deposits (deep chemical weathering) in all the east coast sedimentary basins, particularly during Barremian (Ramkumar et al., 2004) are suggestive of their deposition when remained part of Gondwanaland. These two bouts perhaps accompanied rifting events; the former being a failed rift and the latter, that successfully separated Greater India from Gondwanaland (Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012).
It is to be noted that the western extremities of these renewed faulting followed the EGMB thrust plane, (Fig. 1). While analyzing the paleogeographic assembly of Greater India, Yoshida et al. (1999) recognized a Proterozoic structural element and indicated it as “possible tectonic line.” The Late Jurassic–Early Cretaceous rifting–separation of Indian plate occurred along this line and defines thewestern extremities of all the sedimentary basins and deltas of the ECM, suggestive of recurrent reactivation of inherited zone of weakness. Raval and Veeraswamy (2003) suggested that since Late Jurassic, rifting and breakup of Gondwanaland occurred whenever the Indian plate interacted with plume activity and the breakup occurred along preexistent mobile belts, affirming this inference. This Late Jurassic–Early Cretaceous reactivation has also cut across the failed arms of Gondwana, namely, the Godavari andMahanadi rifts (Figs. 1, 2b, 5).With continued plume activity, associated rift and pull-apart phase, the BOB oceanic crust and ECM of India started evolving. The Precambrian basements that lay west (present day) of the basins provided immature sediments that were deposited as synrift sediments in all the newly formed and rejuvenated basins. Followed is the strike–slip transform faulting and rotation of India and the outpouring of Rajmahal traps that lay over the highly dissected Precambrian basement northwest of Bengal Basin aswell as at the lower part ofMahanadi Basin as subaerial, and subaqueous traps, volcaniclastics, and tuffs. These traps and volcanogenic sedimentary fills evidence the continuation of plume activity of Kerguelen and Crozet plumes until Aptian (Bastia et al., 2010; Radhakrishna et al., 2012a).
With the rotation and pull-apart phases and continued fault block subsidence (probably due to plume ascend and subcrustal erosion), basin differentiation took place that provided accommodation spaces. With due tilt and in response with sea level fluctuations, the basins experienced marine inundations that varied from shallow coastal to deep marine settings. The proto river systems that supplied sediments to the basinmargin synrift depositional settings receded and/or became less active. There are exceptions such as the extensive turbiditic and Gilbert-type deltaic deposition in the Cauvery Basin, where the major tectonic activities during Cenomanian (Ramkumar, 2008) and at the beginning of Santonian (Ramkumar et al., 2005, 2011), respectively, promoted fluvial dominated and/or influenced sedimentation.
Around 88–80 Ma, Madagascar–Seychelles separated from Greater India, forming WCM, coast parallel deep crustal fault (west coast fault/ WCF—refer Fig. 1), and a series of parallel faults that initiated the
formation of WGE. A low-lying coastal plateau, separated from an elevated inland plateau by an erosion-dominant WGE, characterizes the morphology of the west coast—a feature common in other rifted margins as well (Gunnel et al., 2003). Passing of the Indian plate over the Reunion hotspot during 68–64 Ma gave birth to one of the greatest continental flood basalt volcanic episodes in the history of the Earth. Occurrences of more than 5000 m thick trap rocks in Kachchh and Saurastra basins of west coast, and exposures of more than 3500 m thick lava flows (Keller et al., 2009) over the continental basement rocks, that form the vast plateaus in northwestern India, all along the northern part of Western Ghats, evidence the enormity of this volcanic episode. The information that the entire event lasted only a duration of N4 million years and more than 80% of these resultant flows had erupted within 0.8 Ma. (Chenet et al., 2007; Keller et al., 2008) during the regionally correlative C29R magnetic polarity zone (Keller et al., 2009) suggest heightened mantle plume activity at this time.
With the evolution of Arabian Sea oceanic crust, and the northerly drift of Indian plate, the Lakshmi Ridge, Chagos–Laccadive ridge, Carlsberg ridge, etc., came into existence (Bardhan et al., 2002) and the Indian plate recorded the fastest northward drift since then, averaging 20 cm/year (Chatterjee et al., 2013). It could be possible to perceive from the already depleted crust (thin crust) all along the ECM, greater ridge push from south coupled with thinning along WCM due to end Cretaceous volcanism, and could have buoyed the relatively thicker and heavier north–northcentral part of the Indian plate sink and/or slide over the asthenosphere that made the faster flight (Ramkumar et al., 2016). Studies through seismic estimation of the crustal thickness have affirmed the thicker crust under northcentral part (Srinagesh, 2000) and thinnest at the southern extremity of Indian plate (Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003). The occurrences of highest peaks of Western Ghats, exposures of deep crustal rocks along the southern part of the Indian peninsula that indicate extensive denudation than other parts, absence of significant deltas and/or sedimentary basins, coupled with the seismic activities all along the Pre-rift tectonic structures (Figs. 1 and 2c), continued ridge push from Carlsberg and Central Indian ridges (Banerjee et al., 2001), togetherwith ongoing subduction and anticlockwise rotation of Indian plate support this inference, in addition to continuity of the isostatic rebound, due to which the easterly flowing rivers continue to flow since their inception coeval with the evolution of WGE. Continued ridge push, from Carlsberg and Central Indian ridges (Banerjee et al., 2001), as well as pressures from newly emergent and evolving oceanic crust related ridges might have also played a significant role. Rare earth element signatures of Holocene sediments of the Cauvery delta show close affinity with the southern granulite terrain (P. Singh et al., 2015) oblivious to the traditionally considered westerly provenance, affirming the inference of continual uplift and unroofing of the southern extremity of the Indian plate. Pandey (2015) reported that thewestern central part of Peninsular India contains high-density, highvelocity mid-crustal amphibolite to granulite facies rocks due to exhumation of the deeper crustal layers and sustained granitic upper crustal erosion, which adds support to this inference.
The mechanism of prevalent and ongoing geodynamics of denudation of the peninsula is such that the hard collision of Indian plate with Eurasian plate and following subduction and associated anticlockwise rotation of Indian plate created a compressional regime along the ECM and relatively extensional regime along the WCM. The western extremity of Narmada–Son rift had acted and continues to act as the pivotal point for these movements. The west coast fault (WCF) and Panvel flexure acted as the pressure release planes, while aiding unhindered rise of WGE and tilt of Indian plate toward north–east under the influence ridge push. While the Panvel flexure is a prominent feature extending from south of Narmada rift with an NNW–SSE alignment and has been a prominent topographic and structural characteristics readily recognizable in the field as well as in digital elevation model (Hooper et al., 2010) and satellite images, the location of fractures located onland and offshore, aligned parallel–subparallel to this flexure
87M. Ramkumar et al. / Gondwana Research 36 (2016) 65–93
(Fig. 1), and running up to Kerala, are termed as WCF in the literature (e.g., Onland—Banerjee et al., 2001; Biswas, 2005; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012; Offshore—Sukhtankar, 1995; Balakrishnan, 2001; Nair et al., 2008; Avinash et al., 2013). Based on the regional geologic, geomorphic, and field characteristics, we consider that the Panvel flexure is the prime displacement plane, and on the east and west of which there are subparallel fractures (onland and offshore west coast faults) that showdisplacement characteristics. Development ofmultiple, parallel fractures and differential displacements along them is a common phenomenon in regions of major rifting at the continent scale separation.
Along the ECM, the preexistent structural trends of Gondwana and Cretaceous basins were reactivated, particularly all along the EGMB and the tectonic line. Probably, these reactivations were caused by subcrustal phenomenon, as indicated by gravity anomalies beneath these regions as well as thin lithospheric crust (Raval and Veeraswamy, 2003). Extensive deltaic sedimentation commenced all along the east coast during Neogene, with the reactivation of inherited Gondwana structures. Intensive rise of WGE, uplift of southern regions due to isostatic rebound, ridge push, and north–east tilt in addition to the orographic effects provided byWGEhave all contributed toward significant sediment and water influx from the western headlands that made the deltas to prograde 100 km from delta head duringMio-Pliocene. Occurrences of N3000m thickMio-Pliocene continental, coastal, and offshore siliciclastics all along the east coast (Tables 1, 2), especially east of the EGMB (Fig. 1), testify the intensity and sustenance of erosion of headlands and deposition at receiving basins.
Interruptions occurred, in the form of sea level retreat during Miocene due to which, the rivers prograded onto the shelf and incised the former deposits, the relicts of which are seen as terraces (Babu, 1975; Bastia and Radhakrishna, 2012) and incised channel, levee complexes, etc., buried under thick pile of sediment cover. Extensive continental, coastal, and swamp deposits (Tables 1, 2; Mio-Pliocene sandstone, lignite, and clay deposits), to the tune of more than 4500 m thick, occur all along the east coast especially in the region east of EGMB that stand testimony to the continued sediment supply from the Western Ghats. It also evidences to the uplift–unroofing of Western Ghats and subsidence–provision of accommodation space at east of EGMB. The modern deltas are Holocene in origin that made significant strides onto the former shelf regions. The basement structures were active during Quaternary–Recent, both along the west and east coasts, as evident from regionally extensive planation surfaces, incised terraces (Agarwal et al., 1996; Chakrabarti, 2005), coastal cliffs, and wave-cut platforms (Sahayam et al., 2013). Neotectonic activity, seismic tremors, subsidence, anomalous flow courses of channels, changes in strandline locations (Singh et al., 1998) and emergence of beach rocks (Kar, 1993; Ramkumar and Gandhi, 2000; Ramkumar et al., 2000) are all recorded in the east and west coasts that signify the continuing evolution. The coastal geomorphic features and available dating (Wagle et al., 1994; Singh et al., 1998; Nair, 1999; Kunte and Wagle, 2000; Karisiddaiah et al., 2002; Allison et al., 2003; Goodbred, 2003; Jayalakshmi et al., 2004; Bhatt and Bhonde, 2006; Lalbiakzuali et al., 2013; Sarwar and Woodroffe, 2013) suggest a systematic progression of oldest to youngest shorelines from inland to present day shoreline since the dawn of Holocene (Figs. 3, 4) along both the coasts defined by 100 m, 30 m, 10m, and 0 m asl contours signifying Neogene–Recent deltaic and shoreline progradation. Notwithstanding the incised terraces along the continental margin of west coast (Wagle et al., 1994) and in the inland regions as well (Agarwal et al., 1996), 100 m contour defines the Pre-Quaternary terrace, delimiting the residual/ denudational hills and pediments (Babu, 1975), while the 30 m and 10 m elevation contour zones are recognized to be Pleistocene (Singh et al., 1998) and Holocene terraces (Wagle et al., 1994; Singh et al., 1998; Allison et al., 2003; Jayalakshmi et al., 2004; Chakrabarti, 2005; Sahayam et al., 2013), respectively, that occur along both the coastlines. During Holocene, the shoreward progression or younging nature is
indicated by strandlines of ~11,000 yr, 7000–6000 yr, 5000–4000 yr, ~2300 yr, and present day (Figs. 3, 4). Most, if not all, of these terraces and strandlines are either bordered by and/or superimposed over basement faults (Agarwal et al., 1996; Sahayam et al., 2013) of Gondwana structural elements (Figs. 1, 3, 4). Although significant deltaic deposition all along the ECM commenced during Neogene (Singh and Swamy, 2006) specifically during Miocene–Pliocene (under the influence of structural control on denudation of hinterland, and depositional loci and subsidiary role of climate on sediment influx), significant progradation took place since last glacial maximum (LGM; 24–18 Ka) and became intensive since Holocene (particularly 7400–9500 yr when almost all the major deltas of the World started to build extensively—Allison et al., 2003), albeit episodically/cyclically, a fact that correlates well with the general younging nature of the strandlines toward present day coast and position of the Holocene delta heads at about 35–100 km from the shoreline. Corroboration of these progradational episodeswith intensity cycles of SWmonsoon (southwest monsoon was low during the LGM, declined to a minimum from 15,000 to 13,000 yr, intensified slightly at the end of this interval, then was almost stable followed by intensification in two abrupt successions during Younger Dryas, 9900 yr, and during the Early Holocene, 8800 yr—Sirocko et al., 2000) suggests climatic control over deltaic progradation as well. Among the general progradational episodes as indicated by four successive stages, the mid-Holocene has been significant (Srivastava et al., 1994; Agarwal et al., 1996) as evident from maximum advancement over former shelves (Figs. 3, 4). Themid-Holocene (7–3 Ka)was relatively wet and stable (Deo et al., 2010) which affirms the significant role of climate. Collectively, these arguments indicate the following.
a) Although the north–east tilt of India could energize and denude the plateaus and supply enormous sediments to the east coast, and the short rivers of west coast sourced their sediments through headward migration (fluvial recession of the WGE), reactivation of preexistent faults and resultant uplift of Indian plate had been and continue to remain significant at south, perhaps by the Carlsberg and Central Indian ridge push. This means that the easterly tilt could have delimited the western boundaries of east flowing rivers, sedimentary basins, east coast deltas, and eastern boundaries of west-flowing rivers; however, isostatic compensation and northerly push-tiltmight have played the overriding influence ondenudational rates, and locations of active lobes of deltas (paleo and modern). It is further affirmed by the gradual reduction of altitude of delta heads (Table 2) from the Thamirabarani and Vaigai (N70 m amsl), Cauvery (24 m amsl), Krishna (19 m amsl), Godavari (11 m amsl), Mahanadi and Ganges (~10 m amsl). Few other studies (Radhakrishna, 1993; Valdiya and Rajagopalan, 2000; Sharma and Rajamani, 2000a, 2000b; Singh and Rajamani, 2001; Valdiya, 2001b; Sensarma et al., 2008) that examined the lateritic and regolith surfaces of the catchments andfloodplain sediments haveunequivocally established that the Peninsular region, regardless of catchments or deltaic plains, have a youthful character and are evolving, principally under the influence of tectonic activity (Valdiya and Rajagopalan, 2000; Valdiya, 2001a, 2001b; Valdiya, 2008) and aided by monsoonal intensity and pattern; b) The Saurashtra region, located at the juncture of NSL and theWCF, has continued to be tectonically active before and after the outpouring of Deccan basalt. It is evident from the deep seismic imaging of Paleogene deposits that show eustatic sea level cycles, but overprinted by active tectonics in the form of recurrent faulting as observed in the offshore sections and their continuance in the onland equivalents, particularly since the end-Cretaceous volcanism (Pandey et al., 2010). Gunnell (1998b, 1998c) stated that theWesternGhats reveals a trendof surface uplift since the Late Cretaceous due to a strong contribution from flexural rebound by denudational unloading along the edge of an elastic continental slab. c) Under the first-order structural–tectonic control, the modern deltas startedprogradingextensively, the remnants ofwhich are recognizable

Occurrences of paleochannel abandonment traces, significant number of paleoridge-swale complexes along the 5000–3500 yr old strandlines, and paleo-lagoon–beach barrier complexes between these strandlines (Figs. 3, 4) indicate mid-Holocene climate change (Chauhan et al., 2013) influenced phenomenon, superimposed over the primary structural control (Srivastava et al., 1994; Agarwal et al., 1996; Ramkumar, 2000; Ramkumar et al., 2000; Allison et al., 2003; Ramkumar, 2003). Viles and Goudie (2003) opined that though seem to be operating on long-term scales, complex interactions and intricate relations between climate–tectonics also create geomorphic expressions on decadal–millennial scales (Goodbred, 2003). Significant change in sediment influx during the MidHolocene as a result of climatic fluctuation on amillennial year timescale (reduced intensity of SW monsoon) and enforced erosional rates (Kessarkar et al., 2003) was also recorded by Sr–Nd isotopic trends in deltaic and BOB fan sediments (Tripathy et al., 2011). d) Despite the climate-influenced variations on millennial timescales (Goodbred, 2003), the provenance and sediment transport pathways have remained almost similar on Ma timescale since breakup of Gondwana, essentially under the control of tectonics-enforced denudation and locales of deposition (Zhang, 2005). Although this feature is discernible in all the east coast deltas, it is prominent in the Bengal Basin–Ganges delta. Neotectonic movement in the Bengal Basin–Ganges delta (Singh et al., 1998) suggests its easterly tilt (Selvam, 2003); the active delta lobe is also gradually shifting toward east (Sarwar and Woodroffe, 2013), leaving behind moribund delta (Fig. 3) from west to east, confirming the overwhelming influence of active tectonics even in areas of largest sediment influx.

Fig. 11 summarizes the processes that acted since the initial rifting during Permo-Triassic when Indian plate was part of the Gondwana Supercontinent and which are ongoing in the course of tectonogeomorphic evolution of the Peninsular India, based on compilation of the geodynamic, erosional–depositional, geomorphic, climatic, and coastal hydrodynamic histories. sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
• The eastern and western continental margins and the sedimentary basins and deltaic systems of Indian Peninsula have evolved as a tectonic continuum of the pre-breakup Gondwana assembly dating back to Permian (which in turn was inherited from Precambrian structural precursors) and punctuated with tectonic activity, quiescence, and reactivation rather than Late Jurassic–Early Cretaceous commencementwhich, in turn, was a pull-apart phase. Thus, the genesis and evolution of tectonic, geomorphic, drainage and sedimentary basin, coastal and continental margins of Indian subcontinent were influenced largely by and in part inherited from the Gondwanan signatures. • In a number of basins and locations, the older faults and rifts have been, and continue to be, reactivated and formed/form the basis of newer depocenters and geomorphic evolution, in terms of shifting of shoreline, incision and abandoning of channels, activation of delta lobe, creation of terraces (subaerial and subaqueous), and development of growth faults in the offshore deposits, etc. Occurrences of extensive traps of Neocomian–Aptian as trap rocks (Rajmahal Traps) and also subaerial traps over Precambrian basement as well as traps,
es that contribute to the differential topographic evolution of east andwest coasts of India.
tuff, and intertrappeans with subaerial and subaqueous characteristics in the Mahanadi and Bengal basins suggest that following the Kerguelen plume-related crustal thinning in association with preexistent weak planes of basin margin faults of pre-breakup Gondwana basins might have initiated breakup and actual separation of Greater India from Gondwanaland. • General parallel trends of post-breakupbasin faults and their differentiation into horsts and grabens with similar trends suggest the evolution of the east coast basins as inherited and/or antecedent structural evolution. Typically, the Bengal Basin and less typically the Mahanadi and Krishna–Godavari basins exemplify this phenomenon, while the Cauvery Basin shows fresh downwarping that occurred during breakup. This could be due to the progression of subcrustal plume movement from Bengal Basin toward southern part of India and followed-up right lateral transform faulting and rotation of India after breakup. • The WCM of India came into existence since the breakup of Madagascar–Seychelles–India approximately around 88–80 Ma. It was followed by plume-related uplift, west coast faulting, and outpouring of Deccan Lava during 68–64 Ma. Later, differentiation of WCM intomany strike–slip faults related horsts and grabens occurred due to continued rifting and drifting along Lakshmi ridge, Chagos– Laccadive ridge, and Carlsberg ridge. The north–east tilt of Indian plate and subduction and anticlockwise rotation of Indian plate contributed significantly on the macrogeomorphic evolution of the west coast thenceforth. Superimposed on these major, crustal scale geodynamics are the effects of the WGE and resultant orographyenhanced precipitation, headward erosion of channels and resultant receding of escarpment, stream capture, and formation of water divide along the peaks of Western Ghats, that define the shorter, straight channels and estuaries of west coast. • Eastward flow of all the major rivers of Peninsula owes its allegiance to the rifting followed by pull-apart and associated upward tilt from
SW–NE, relatively higher subduction of Indian plate and higher sediment loading along NE part, together with anticlockwise rotation of the Indian plate due to the relatively higher rate of subduction. While these act as the first-order control, alignment of Western Ghats, Deccan traps, and resultant enforcement of principal catchments there, aided by general slope toward east favored diversion of peninsular rivers toward east, and these factors played secondary control. Reactivations of Gondwanan rift-related basin margin and mid-Cretaceous faults have provided accommodation spaces for the coastal deltas thatwere established during Cretaceous, energized during Quaternary and are being sustained by the climate. These factors acted as tertiary control. The landscape is still young and evolving, as explicit in the occurrences of numerous knickpoints/waterfalls in almost all the major river courses, very thin regolith cover over Archean and Proterozoic rocks, texturally immature sediments in the peninsular river channel and flood plains, and incidences of earthquakes and alignments of Quaternary–Recent river channels in, along, and in the vicinity of older faults and thrusts, etc. • Coincidental with hard collision of Indian plate with Eurasia, energized by uplift and tilt and supported by significant erosion of catchments, the east coast basins started developing deltaic systems antecedent over marine depositional systems. While sea level fluctuations could have played a role in such change, limiting of westward boundary of all the deltas except Ganges by the tectonic line of EGMB and the general anticlockwise rotation and subduction-related crustal shortening suggest first-order structural control (which in turnmight have enforced sea level retreat) followed by establishment of monsoon system and significant discharge through the fluvial systems as the secondary control. This is supported by the welldocumented significant progradation of all the east coast deltas that took place since last 8–10 Ma, coincidental with the establishment of WGE as an orographic barrier. Although it started evolving since 88–80 Ma, WGE underwent accelerated uplift since 68–64 Ma and

It might have reached the threshold by 10–8Ma, coincidental with the establishment of SWmonsoon. • In this study, we have recognized three major controls/processes according to their relative influence on tectono-geomorphic evolution of the Indian plate. Recognition of tectonics as the first-order control on basin evolution and landscape development has been well established with rifting and subcrustal tectonic processes exerting the primary control. The resultant landscape development and its positive feedback on the tectonic forces by either augmenting or decelerating the rate of tectonic movement have been considered as secondary, essentially due to its relative role with reference to the contribution by basement tectonics. The basinfill, shifting of prime loci of deposition, and their feedback on basement tectonics are considered tertiary as they played subordinate role to tectonics and landscape evolution. These controls may have acted continually as secondary and tertiary controls in response to the primary control and topographic feedback on basement tectonics. Hence, we consider them to be a dynamic continuum, rather than cause–effect. This postulate, together with the tectono-geomorphic model presented in our study, demonstrates the inheritance and continuum of Gondwanan structural trends on transient landscape of the Indian peninsula. • The tectono-geomorphic model synthesizes the regional trends and major structural features of the Peninsular India. Applicability of this model in explaining regional/basin scale characteristics needs to be tested with specific case studies on each of the sedimentary basins.

Ramkumar obtained his bachelor degree in geology from National College, Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirapalli, masters in geology from Annamalai University, Chidambaram, and PhD in Earth Sciences, from Bharathidasan University. His research interests range from Recent–Paleozoic depositional systems and integrated sequence–chemostratigraphy, and basin evolution. He has published about 100 articles in national and international journals, edited volumes and conference proceedings. He is the author of 4 books (Cretaceous Sea Level Cycles, Marine Paleobiodiversity, Chemostratigraphy, River Basin etc.) and editor of 5 special volumes published by Elsevier, Springer etc. He is a member of National Working Group on IGCP−609 Cretaceous Sea Level Cycles. Since completion of his PhD, he worked as research team lead-
er and member in national international labs in India, Germany, Malaysia. He was the recipient of the prestigious Alexander Von Humboldt Fellowship, Visiting Scientist (thrice), Germany, Young Scientist (twice), Government of India, and was included in the Marquee's Who's Who directory (USA) for 5 consecutive years. abstractText: Handling Editor: T. Tsunogae The Indian subcontinent comprises accreted cratonic fragments that underwent subsequent rifting–subduction– collision processes along major mobile belts. It is also a storehouse of a prolonged history of crustal evolution involving repeated episodes of magmatism, volcanism, sedimentation, and metamorphism, and the formation of intracratonic and foreland basins. The geologic–geomorphic evolution of the Peninsula is recorded in relic faults/suture zones that confine Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic sedimentary basins and landforms. In addition, escarpments, plateaus, waterfalls, deltas, planation surfaces, and strandlines are either aligned parallel and/or formed over them. Asymmetric relief across thewestern–eastern parts of the Peninsula, orographic effect on the precipitation pattern and climatic zones provide important constrains on the geologic and geomorphic evolution of the region. Though extensive continental and coastal deposition occurred during Permo-Triassic and Early Cretaceous, only the downwarped grabens of Gondwana basins preserved the sedimentary records. Occurrences of extensive Cenozoic deposits offshore and Neogene–Holocene deltaic deposits along the entire east coast as opposed to the absence of comparable deltaic sequences in the west coast are linked to intense and recurrent episodes of denudation indicating first-order control of basement structures over landscape evolution. Inheritance and continuum of basement structures over climate, and landscape evolution of Peninsular India can also be witnessed by the unique and diverse drainage patterns of major rivers. While most of the major rivers follow a general easterly direction, the landscape morphology of their catchments indicates youthful character and tectonically active nature. The east flowing rivers show an asymmetry between the areal extents of drainage basin size and delta,whereas thewest-flowing rivers are short and straight and their catchments areminiscule in comparisonwith the rivers flowing toward east. TheWestern Ghats Escarpment forms an orographic barrier and acts as themain divide between these two drainage systems. There is a disparity between the quanta of sediment discharge aswell. In addition, the eastern andwestern parts of India, across theWestern Ghats Escarpment, show significant differences in terms of climatic zones (humid to per-humid on thewestwhile it is arid to subhumid on the east). The west coast is characterized by N3000 mm/year annual rainfall, that often reaches N5000mm/year, dominance of SWmonsoonwinds, occurrence of narrow (b60 km), rocky, crenulated and coastal cliffs and pocket beaches, and net southerly long shore sediment transport. In contrast, the east coast is characterized by several hundred kilometers wide deltaic low lands built by major rivers. These rivers show trellis to dendritic stream patterns and follow major basement faults that are associated with geologic–historic–recent seismic activity. The sedimentary basins and delta heads, strandlines, and active delta lobes whose western boundary is always limited by basement faults have shown activity since the formation of the Gondwanan supercontinent. The eastern coastal region is also different from the west in terms of active NE monsoon, long shore sediment transport (toward north), and the formation of extensive lagoon-beach barrier systems sinceNeogene that in turn continue to occur until recent. Here we propose a conceptual tectono-geomorphic model demonstrating the inheritance and continuum of Gondwanan structural trends on the transient landscape of Peninsular India. © 2016 International Association for Gondwana Research.
